DataElement.preferredName: University of Washington Quality of Life Questionnaire Most Important Issues Past 7 Days Cancer Anxiety 4 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A person's stated perception of their anxiety as related to their cancer in the past seven days, using a 4 point Likert scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: University of Washington Quality of Life Questionnaire Most Important Issues Past 7 Days Cancer Anxiety
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A questionnaire designed to assess health-related quality of life in head and neck cancer patients._A question about a person's most important health issues._The most recent week, including today._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._Apprehension of danger and dread accompanied by restlessness, tension, tachycardia, and dyspnea unattached to a clearly identifiable stimulus.

ObjectClass.preferredName: University of Washington Quality of Life Scale, Version 4
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A questionnaire designed to assess health-related quality of life in head and neck cancer patients.

Concepts.longName: University of Washington Quality of Life Scale, Version 4
Concepts.definition: A questionnaire designed to assess health-related quality of life in head and neck cancer patients.

Property.preferredName: Most Important Issue Past Week Malignant Neoplasm Anxiety
Property.preferredDefinition: A question about a person's most important health issues.:The most recent week, including today.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.:Apprehension of danger and dread accompanied by restlessness, tension, tachycardia, and dyspnea unattached to a clearly identifiable stimulus.

Concepts.definition: A question about a person's most important health issues.
The most recent week. May include the present day.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Apprehension of danger and dread accompanied by restlessness, tension, tachycardia, and dyspnea unattached to a clearly identifiable stimulus.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An ordered reference standard of four responses from not anxious to very anxious about cancer.

PermissibleValues.value: I am very anxious about my cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating that an individual is very anxious about their cancer.

Concepts.definition: A response indicating that an individual is very anxious about their cancer.

PermissibleValues.value: I am anxious about my cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating that an individual is anxious about their cancer.

Concepts.definition: A response indicating that an individual is anxious about their cancer.

PermissibleValues.value: I am a little anxious about my cancer.
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: A Little Anxious About My Cancer

ValueMeaning.preferredName: A Little Anxious About My Cancer
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating that an individual is a little anxious about their cancer.

Concepts.longName: A Little Anxious About My Cancer
Concepts.definition: A response indicating that an individual is a little anxious about their cancer.

PermissibleValues.value: I am not anxious about my cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating that an individual is not anxious about their cancer.
